qas.question: Who directed the purges of Soviets?
Who were sent to replace the expelled positions?
What did this cause when the expelled parties were replaced?

answers.text: subsequently Russians dominated party positions at all levels, including the top position of first secretary

qas.question: What did the population of Russians do between 1926-1959?
How many purges resulted in the expulsion of nearly 100,000 people?
What group did not dominate any party positions?
Between 1916 and 1959, which population grew to 13%?
How many rounds of Soviet purges were directed by Manhattan?

context: <b5_0><b8_0>Two<b8_0/><b5_0/> rounds of Soviet purges directed by <a0_0>Moscow<a0_0/> (1927–1934 and 1937–1938) resulted in the expulsion of <a1_0>nearly 10,000 people<a1_0/>, from all levels of the Communist Party of Tajikistan. <a2_0>Ethnic Russians<a2_0/> were sent in to replace those expelled and <a3_0>subsequently <b6_0>Russians<b6_0/> dominated party positions at all levels, including the top position of first secretary<a3_0/>. Between 1926 and 1959 the proportion of <b7_0>Russians<b7_0/> among Tajikistan's population <a4_0>grew from less than 1% to 13%<a4_0/>. Bobojon Ghafurov, Tajikistan's First Secretary of the Communist Party of Tajikistan from 1946–1956 was the only Tajikistani politician of significance outside of the country during the Soviet Era. He was followed in office by Tursun Uljabayev (1956–61), Jabbor Rasulov (1961–1982), and Rahmon Nabiyev (1982–1985, 1991–1992).
